portabout.para: NetBSD/hpcmips brings the NetBSD operating system to MIPS based Windows CE PDA machines. Currently, the VR4102, VR4111, VR4121, VR4122, VR4131, TX3912, and TX3922 processors are supported.

The port name "hpcmips" comes from the name for some of the hardware that NetBSD/hpcmips runs on: MIPS based systems in Microsoft's H/PC (Handheld PC) form factor. A H/PC machine contains a keyboard and a touch screen and generally has 8MB or more of RAM. The port supports the HPC form factor, as well as the H/PC Pro and PsPC (Palmsized PC) form factors. (Many PsPC machines are used by the developers for active development.)

Because of the hardware platforms it supports, NetBSD/hpcmips is an ideal platform to use for mobile computing applications. And, of course, NetBSD/hpcmips supports all of the standard features you expect from NetBSD, such as IPv6 and IPsec.

portinfo.portlinkitem: GXemul, a functional machine emulator which also emulates NEC MobilePro 770/800.

portnews.portnewsitem: NetBSD 5.0 has been released. More information is available in the 5.0 release announcement.
NetBSD 4.0.1 has been released. More information is available in the 4.0.1 release announcement.
NetBSD 4.0 released with support for 54 architectures. More information is available in the 4.0 release announcement.

NetBSD 3.1, the first maintenance release of the netbsd-3 release branch, has been released with binary distributions for 53 architectures. More information is available in the 3.1 release announcement.
NetBSD 3.0 released with support for 57 architectures. More information is available in the 3.0 release announcement.
Audio Interface Unit Driver for VR4121 had merged into NetBSD-current by Katsuomi HAMAJIMA.

portsection.title: Supported System Models
portsection.para: Many kinds of H/PC, H/PC Pro, and PsPC systems are supported by NetBSD/hpcmips. View the supported system table to see if your system is supported.

portsection.title: Supported Processors
portsection.para: VR4102, VR4111, VR4121, VR4131, TX3912, and TX3922 processors are supported by NetBSD/hpcmips. View the processor comparison table to see if your processor is supported.

listitem.para: Cassiopeia E-500 has NM2004COM2K in it.
Cassiopeia E-11 has Casio-branded IC, marked "UPD65843-Y03" and "9829KU203" in it.
It seems that they aren't compatible with generic PCIC.
Need keymap information in world model.

portsection.title: Keyboard map search method for unknown machines

itemizedlist.listitem: Press keys and note the KeyScanCode's.
Fill vr/vrkiu.c default_keytrans[] with scancode, dev/pckbc/wskbdmap_mfii.c:pckbd_keydesc_us[] is KeyCodeMapping.
Send feedback with your results using &man.send-pr.1; (port-hpcmips category).
